awd_titl_txt: The STEMPath Approach: Success for Low Income Students
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will provide a cohort of 14 low-income, academically talented students with multi-year financial support to pursue a STEM major at Coe College in Iowa. This S-STEM Track 1 project will guide these Pell-eligible students to graduation through a four-year program called STEMPath designed to help them persist and succeed in a STEM major in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, or Mathematics/Computer Science. The STEMPath program will also provide these students support beyond direct financial aid in the form of social and academic connections, skills training, career option exposure, research and internship experiences, peer education, work study and mentoring experiences, and access to additional pre-college orientation and trained instructional specialists. Key program highlights will include: first-year bridge activities, participation in a Living and Learning community, and academic coaching. During their second year, scholars will enjoy alumni mentoring and a summer research exposure, followed by a full internship/research experience in their third year. Finally, as seniors, the scholarship recipients will receive job and graduate school exposure and application guidance. Students will meet every semester with selected STEM faculty to monitor their progress in the STEMPath program and receive additional guidance. This project will thus help at-risk students successfully navigate and complete their chosen STEM major.

This S-STEM project seeks to address common pitfalls for academically talented Pell-eligible students. Most notably, the project seeks to monitor and address first-year student retention and STEM persistence issues for introductory courses. Four goals guide the work of the principal investigators. First, the faculty seek to increase the first-year retention and STEM persistence rate of scholarship students in the introductory courses to match that of non-Pell grant students. Second, the project will increase the overall graduation rate of STEMPath students to at least 86% (12/14). Third, the project intends to provide all scholarship recipients with significant career-training experiences including a full summer of scientific research. Finally, the project seeks to increase the average graduation GPA of its students from 3.12 to at least 3.3. Faculty mentors will guide students from before entering first-year orientation through a mentored research experience anchored in Coe's NSF-REU program through graduation and into STEM graduate work or careers. The influence of faculty mentors as well as other social, academic, and professional connections will also be assessed for effectiveness in retention and STEM persistence. Findings will be disseminated regarding the effectiveness of support services, social adjustment, and summer research experience in assisting Pell-eligible students who are provided financial relief through this S-STEM project.

por.por_cntn:
This project, "The STEMPath Approach: Success for Low Income Students," was successful in favorably impacting the lives of 15 undergraduate students at Coe College with majors in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math), while simultaneously bolstering the institutional resources for all future STEM students at Coe.  Coe is a small, undergraduate-only, liberal arts college with a strong reputation for STEM programs, including being selected as a host site for the National Science Foundation's prestigious Research Experience for Undergraduates (NSF REU) program.  Combining the research acumen of the science faculty with the Federal TRIO program available in Coe's Learning Commons (educational opportunity outreach programs designed to motivate and support students from disadvantaged backgrounds) created an ideal situation to try new ways to increase success for low income students majoring in STEM.

Pell-grant eligible students with strong motivation for science were selected to participate as STEMPath Scholars.  We provided a "bridge program" to help these students transition to college before Freshman year.  We also provided a Freshman "living-learning community," science and career programming, increased mentoring, and extensive STEM research training, among other opportunities.  During their time at Coe, the students also received a substantial scholarship to reduce the financial burden of attending college.  Intended majors of our Scholars included Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.

The STEMPath project studied the problems of low STEM retention and persistence.  We gathered data on successful college completion for underrepresented and economically-challenged students in STEM.  Our data, although limited by a small sample size (only 15 students), indicates that connection to the college can be an important factor in the students’ acclimatization to the challenging college environment.  Most importantly, we saw that participation in early research experiences correlated with increased persistence in a chosen STEM major.  Successful students in the STEMPath program unanimously rated research/practicum experiences and NSF scholarship money as the two elements that were "very helpful" to "essential" for them to continue in college and persist in finishing their STEM major.

By providing at least one, but up to three, paid internship or research experiences to every STEMPath Scholar, the STEMPath program at Coe succeeded in offering both financial support and experiential training to economically-disadvantaged students.  These students were able to broaden their horizons and experience aspects of STEM fields that are often difficult to access, such as working one-on-one with a professor on a research project and presenting their findings at symposia.  STEMPath Scholars not only met with their STEMPath Mentors but also communicated directly with the program director to discuss their paid internship, practicum, and research experiences.  Thus, guidance, mentorship, and experiential learning each played a role in helping to nurture and train future scientists.

In addition, the majority of STEMPath Scholars completing the program gained experience in STEM teaching and mentoring as juniors and seniors by working in the Learning Commons, Coe College's student support center.  Aided by this grant, the institutional STEM resources of Coe’s Learning Commons were expanded to now include: increased space for "Peer2Peer" tutoring, quadrupled Supplemental Instruction courses available, increased training of student Supplemental Instructors, hired professional support staff for one-on-one STEM help (including a full-time Master's Degree biologist), and quadrupled online study resources available for students in STEM courses.  Those Scholars who worked in the Learning Commons served the college as tutors, peer mentors, and SI leaders, whereas others worked as research students and trainers.  These Scholars as a group are thus better prepared for future STEM teaching and graduate education.

This project has impacted several STEM fields by increasing the socioeconomic diversity of undergraduates in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.  Nine STEMPath Scholars completed the program in Spring 2022.  They are now working as scientists in food production and water quality studies, and as computer scientists in the financial sector, or attending graduate school in geosciences, atmospheric and oceanic science, and computer science.  Four are pursuing graduate and professional school education in healthcare-related careers.  The STEM research training of these students through the STEMPath program at Coe has strengthened their understanding of basic and translational research, and thus will enable them to incorporate scientific findings more readily in their service to the community.

This project has strengthened America by affording opportunities to low income families who normally would struggle to provide meaningful educational opportunities to their bright and capable children.  The STEMPath Program provided increased support, motivation, mentoring, and experience to study and enhance retention in higher education and persistence in STEM majors.  The end result will be higher-paying careers and upward social mobility for students and their families.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: Randolph Christensen
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project, "The STEMPath Approach: Success for Low Income Students," was successful in favorably impacting the lives of 15 undergraduate students at Coe College with majors in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math), while simultaneously bolstering the institutional resources for all future STEM students at Coe.  Coe is a small, undergraduate-only, liberal arts college with a strong reputation for STEM programs, including being selected as a host site for the National Science Foundation's prestigious Research Experience for Undergraduates (NSF REU) program.  Combining the research acumen of the science faculty with the Federal TRIO program available in Coe's Learning Commons (educational opportunity outreach programs designed to motivate and support students from disadvantaged backgrounds) created an ideal situation to try new ways to increase success for low income students majoring in STEM.

Pell-grant eligible students with strong motivation for science were selected to participate as STEMPath Scholars.  We provided a "bridge program" to help these students transition to college before Freshman year. During their time at Coe, the students also received a substantial scholarship to reduce the financial burden of attending college.  Intended majors of our Scholars included Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.

The STEMPath project studied the problems of low STEM retention and persistence.  We gathered data on successful college completion for underrepresented and economically-challenged students in STEM.  Our data, although limited by a small sample size (only 15 students), indicates that connection to the college can be an important factor in the students’ acclimatization to the challenging college environment.  Most importantly, we saw that participation in early research experiences correlated with increased persistence in a chosen STEM major.  Successful students in the STEMPath program unanimously rated research/practicum experiences and NSF scholarship money as the two elements that were "very helpful" to "essential" for them to continue in college and persist in finishing their STEM major.

By providing at least one, but up to three, paid internship or research experiences to every STEMPath Scholar, the STEMPath program at Coe succeeded in offering both financial support and experiential training to economically-disadvantaged students. STEMPath Scholars not only met with their STEMPath Mentors but also communicated directly with the program director to discuss their paid internship, practicum, and research experiences. In addition, the majority of STEMPath Scholars completing the program gained experience in STEM teaching and mentoring as juniors and seniors by working in the Learning Commons, Coe College's student support center.  Aided by this grant, the institutional STEM resources of Coe’s Learning Commons were expanded to now include: increased space for "Peer2Peer" tutoring, quadrupled Supplemental Instruction courses available, increased training of student Supplemental Instructors, hired professional support staff for one-on-one STEM help (including a full-time Master's Degree biologist), and quadrupled online study resources available for students in STEM courses.  Those Scholars who worked in the Learning Commons served the college as tutors, peer mentors, and SI leaders, whereas others worked as research students and trainers.  These Scholars as a group are thus better prepared for future STEM teaching and graduate education.

This project has impacted several STEM fields by increasing the socioeconomic diversity of undergraduates in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics.  Nine STEMPath Scholars completed the program in Spring 2022.  They are now working as scientists in food production and water quality studies, and as computer scientists in the financial sector, or attending graduate school in geosciences, atmospheric and oceanic science, and computer science.  Four are pursuing graduate and professional school education in healthcare-related careers.  The STEM research training of these students through the STEMPath program at Coe has strengthened their understanding of basic and translational research, and thus will enable them to incorporate scientific findings more readily in their service to the community.

This project has strengthened America by affording opportunities to low income families who normally would struggle to provide meaningful educational opportunities to their bright and capable children.  The STEMPath Program provided increased support, motivation, mentoring, and experience to study and enhance retention in higher education and persistence in STEM majors.  The end result will be higher-paying careers and upward social mobility for students and their families.
